text: Within this executive team, sensitive issues and bad news are shared promptly and candidly.
I believe my peers on this team consistently act in the best interests of the enterprise, even when it conflicts with their functional agenda.
I am comfortable admitting to this team when I have made a mistake or misjudgment.
I trust my colleagues on this team to follow through on commitments made in our meetings.
Decisions we make as an executive team are transparent in rationale to each other, even when we disagree.
We speak with one voice after decisions are made, regardless of prior debate in the room.
I believe others on this team would actively support me if I faced a major setback or external challenge.
I feel safe raising ethical or reputational concerns, even if they slow down attractive opportunities.
In this team, we take time to understand each other’s functional and personal constraints before pushing for decisions.
My peers show genuine interest in my pressures rather than dismissing them as excuses.
When conflict arises, we work to understand underlying concerns rather than treating it as a win–lose argument.
As a team, we consider the human impact on employees and customers when making major decisions.
Members of this team are willing to flex timelines when a colleague is managing a critical personal issue.
We actively seek to understand how our decisions land on middle managers and frontline teams.
I feel I can surface concerns about my own wellbeing without being perceived as weak.
We role-model listening and empathy, knowing it sets the tone for the organization.
As an executive team, we have a shared, specific view of enterprise strategy over the next 3–5 years.
We are aligned on the few critical priorities that must be delivered in the next 12–24 months.
Our functional goals are explicitly linked to agreed enterprise priorities.
We make decisions primarily from an enterprise perspective, not functional turf.
We provide the organization with consistent messages about strategy and priorities.
Our resource allocation matches our stated strategic priorities.
We have clear decision rights and governance for major enterprise choices.
We regularly review and adjust priorities together in response to external shifts.
We visibly close the loop with the organization on big decisions.
As an executive team, we share a compelling story of why our organization exists.
I personally feel a strong sense of purpose in the work we do as an executive team.
Our discussions connect strategic decisions back to mission and values.
We consider long-term value creation in strategic trade-offs.
We ensure purpose and values guide behavior in crises.
People across levels would recognize the same core purpose we describe.
My work on this executive team aligns with my personal values.
We actively steward organizational culture.
I can raise dissenting views without fear of negative career consequences.
We can admit when we do not know something without losing credibility.
When risks are raised, we respond with curiosity, not defensiveness.
Robust debate is welcomed when handled respectfully.
We surface and learn from failures openly.
I feel safe naming issues in our own executive team effectiveness.
Direct reports can bring problems and half-baked ideas without fear.
Our behavior makes it easier for teams below us to speak up.
